Discriminatory policies in the South, such as segregation, racism, and limited economic opportunities, motivated many African Americans to migrate North during the Great Migration. The Jim Crow laws enforced racial segregation, which led to unequal treatment and separate, but unequal facilities for African Americans. They were barred from voting, attending quality schools, and owning property, and those who challenged the status quo faced persecution and violence. As a result, many African Americans sought better opportunities beyond the oppressive conditions of the South. 

The North, although not free from racism, presented more promising prospects for African Americans. They were able to find jobs in factories and the service sector, access education and public facilities, and participate in civic life. They were also able to form communities and organizations that advocated for their rights and worked towards equality. 

Therefore, discriminatory policies in the South played a significant role in the decision of African Americans to migrate North during the Great Migration. They were motivated by the desire to escape oppressive conditions, seek better opportunities and freedoms, and build a better future for themselves and their families.
